data.title: This time, Khairy runs with the wind behind his back
data.meta_description:
When Khairy Jamaluddin (pic) contested and narrowly won the top position in Umno Youth in 2009, he did so pretty much on his own steam.

	His biggest backer, then-Prime Minister and father-in-law Tun Abdullah Ahmad Badawi was a lame duck, on the ropes following the disastrous performance in GE12 where Barisan Nasional (BN) lost its two-thirds...
data.text:
When Khairy Jamaluddin (pic) contested and narrowly won the top position in Umno Youth in 2009, he did so pretty much on his own steam.

His biggest backer, then-Prime Minister and father-in-law Tun Abdullah Ahmad Badawi was a lame duck, on the ropes following the disastrous performance in GE12 where Barisan Nasional (BN) lost its two-thirds majority for the first time in history.

Khairy bagged 304 votes, winning by a 50-vote majority over Dr Mohd Khir Toyo and Datuk Seri Mukhriz Mahathir.

Yesterday, he announced that he will defend the top post in the youth wing.

"After consulting my Umno Youth colleagues, I am requesting for one more term because there is work still to be done," he was quoted as saying by Malaysiakini.

This time, though, he will be going into the contest as the favourite, and not only because of the advantage of incumbency but because he is now Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Razak's go-to-guy.

After years of seeing Khairy as just an Abdullah loyalist, Najib now sees him as a useful ally in his own fight to defend his Umno presidency as well as to reach out to young Malaysians.

That is why Najib appointed him to the Cabinet, despite behind-the-scenes objections from those aligned to Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad, the former prime minister who alleged that Khairy had too much influence over Abdullah when the latter was the PM.

Some of the Dr Mahathir camp's antipathy towards Khairy flared up again following the coverage of the book titled Awakening: The Abdullah Badawi Years In Malaysia.

Some of them accused Khairy of being the hidden hand behind the publication, which featured critical comments from Abdullah against Dr Mahathir, a rarity.

The book, a collection of interviews and essays on Abdullah, was co-edited by Dr Bridget Welsh and Dr James Chin. - August 19, 2013.
